div.p: This paper is concerned with the simultaneous design of a fuzzy-based output feedback control law and an adaptive event-triggering condition for a class of single-input and singleoutput (SISO) uncertain nonlinear systems in the presence of a communication channel between the plant and the controller. To this aim, a Lyapunov-based technique is adopted in an impulsive dynamic system framework to ensure local stability and tracking performance. The proposed Lyapunov formulation yields an event-triggered algorithm to update the control input and fuzzy weights based on conditions involving the closed-loop state, which are aperiodically updated only at the event-sampled instants. Furthermore, a positive lower bound on the minimum inter-sample time is guaranteed to avoid accumulation point. Different from the existing traditional time-triggered control schemes, the developed method samples the state and updates the controller and fuzzy weights only when it is necessary. Clearly, this can largely decrease the communication burden of the communication network. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is illustrated using simulation examples.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: The stabilization and tracking control of nonlinear systems have become one of the most important and popular field in modern control theory since a large number of practical systems could be modeled by nonlinear dynamic equations, such as near space vehicle control systems, mechatronic and mechanical systems, chemical processes and nonholonomic mobile robots. So far, many significant methodologies have been developed for nonlinear systems such as robust control [1], adaptive backstepping control [2] and Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy-model-based control technique [3]. Especially, the backstepping-based adaptive control technique is conceptually simple and effective for controlling complex nonlinear systems [4]. It is worthy mentioning that the aforementioned approaches are all developed based on the assumption that the uncertainties are linearly parametrized, which is strict for some practical control systems [6].

To overcome this difficulty, some efficient control methods, such as fuzzy control [5], and neural control [6] have been developed due to their excellent approximation abilities, which can combine the advantages of adaptive backstepping technique and fuzzy logic systems or neural networks. Many achievements have been obtained for various types of nonlinear systems [7]- [19]. However, these methods are all developed based on the traditional time-triggered strategy where the control execution is periodic. This may lead to an unnecessary fast sampling rate and then to an over-usage of communication resources [20]. In particular, when the communication and energy resources are limited, the huge number of transmitted data often leads to heavy communication burden.

To mitigate the unnecessary waste of communication resources, the event-triggered control (ETC) has gained more and more interest, both in theory and in application. In this context, an event-triggering condition is required to determine the triggering instants when the sampled-data is transmitted, which usually consists of the event-trigger error and a predefined threshold [20]- [22]. The control task is executed only when the event-trigger error exceeds the specified threshold. As a consequence, the consumption of communication resources can be largely decreased [23]. Note that the common feature of [24]- [26] are implemented for nonlinear systems based on the input to-state stability (ISS) assumption which implies the existence of a feedback control law ensuring an ISS property with respect to measurement errors. As shown in [27], the ISS property does always hold whenever the closedloop system is ISS in the classical sense. For these reasons, the design of both the controller and the event-triggering condition simultaneously has been proposed in [28], [29]. However, it should be pointed out that the developed techniques in [28], [29] are only effective for nonlinear systems with matched uncertainties.

Recently, an adaptive ETC method was developed in [30] for a class of strict feedback SISO nonlinear systems. However, the aforementioned approach on adaptive ETC is restricted to the case of state feedback which requires the availability of full state information. Clearly, it is impossible to employ a state feedback law in most of the cases, since the full state information is not available for measurement in practice. For this reason, it is important and necessary to study event-triggered network control systems (NCSs) subject to uncertainties that rely on output measurements only. Though some results on output feedback problem have been obtained in [31]- [36] for the co-design problem, they are limited to a class of linear systems or a class of nonlinear systems with exactly known dynamics. As mentioned above, however, system uncertainties widely exist in many practical systems. Therefore, the approaches cannot be applied to more general nonlinear system with unknown nonlinear functions. It is meaningful and challenging to address the observer-based ETC co-design problem for more general nonlinear systems, which motivated the presented work.

Motivated by this insight, we provide a novel framework for the construction of event-triggered output-feedback controller for a class of SISO uncertain nonlinear continuous-time systems. In contrast with the aforementioned references, the main contributions of the work can be summarized as follows:

1) An adaptive event-triggered communication scheme with a dynamically adjustable threshold is presented by using backstepping and event-triggered methods. 2) Compared with the traditional observer-based fuzzy control schemes for strict-feedback nonlinear systems with a continuous transmission [7], [8], the proposed method only uses the triggered samples to update the state and the control law, which can largely reduce the transmission load. 3) Unlike the event-trigged state feedback control scheme [30], a novel mixed event-trigger output feedback control scheme is designed for mismatched uncertain nonlinear dynamics.

The "explosion of complexity" problem when applying the backstepping recursive design scheme is overcome by exploiting event-based virtual controller, which is different from the current state of the art [19]. Remark 5. It is worth noticing that, in the proof of Theorem 1, the problem of "explosion of complexity" caused by the repeated differentiations of virtual controllers [7] is effectively overcome by exploiting event-based virtual control (since in each step, αi = 0). Such a method is different from the classic dynamic surface control method in [19] where first-order filters are introduced. By taking advantage of this property, the computational burden can be largely reduced.

Remark 6. Theoretically speaking, we can arbitrarily increase k i and l i to achieve exceptional tracking performance. Nevertheless, from ( 25), ( 26) and ( 78), increasing k i and l i may increase the amplitude of control signals. As a result, a tradeoff should be made between the tracking performance and the control effort.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: In this paper, an observer-based fuzzy adaptive eventtriggered control co-design problem has been investigated for a class of uncertain nonlinear continuous-time system in strict feedback form. The novel adaptive event-trigger condition was designed as a function of fuzzy weight estimates in order to save the communication resource and transmission load. The designed weight tuning law and the controller were tuned in an aperiodic manner at the event sampled instants. The event sampled closed-loop system is formulated as a nonlinear impulsive dynamical system and the stability of the close-loop system was confirmed by extension of Lyapunov approach for both the continuous and the jump dynamics. The simulation results show the effectiveness of the proposed method and also verified the theoretical analysis.
